org.gearvrf.io.cursor3d

Class Cursor

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.io.cursor3d.Cursor

  • public abstract class Cursor
extends java.lang.Object
    Represents a 3D cursor in GVRf, it encapsulates the intended behavior from a device controlled 3D object.

    While the application cannot create a Cursor object. There are two ways to obtain one:

    • Query the CursorManager for the currently available cursor objects using CursorManager.getActiveCursors(). This call requests the CursorManager for all the active Cursor objects with the CursorManager.
    • Use the CursorActivationListener to know about Cursor objects added or removed from the CursorManager during runtime.

    As a general rule it an application would query the CursorManager for all available Cursor objects on initialization using (1) and get updates about objects added or removed during runtime using (2). Changes made to the CursorManager can lead to the addition or removal of Cursorobjects. For eg. switching CursorTypes or setting a new IoDevice that supports multiple Cursor objects.

    Each Cursor object has a CursorType that defines the type of events generated.

    • Method Detail

      • setCursorTheme

        public void setCursorTheme(CursorTheme theme)
        Set a CursorTheme for this cursor. Use the CursorManager.getCursorThemes() call to know all the available cursor themes. Make sure that the theme cursor type matches this Cursor else this call will return an IllegalArgumentException.
        Parameters:
        theme - the CursorTheme to be set.

      • getCursorTheme

        public CursorTheme getCursorTheme()
        Use this call to return the currently set CursorTheme.
        Returns:
        the currently set CursorTheme

      • getCursorType

        public CursorType getCursorType()
        Get the type of this Cursor object. Look at CursorType to know more about the various types of cursor objects created by the CursorManager.
        Returns:
        the CursorType of this Cursor object.

        Parameters:
        x - x value of the position
        y - y value of the position
        z - z value of the position

      • invalidate

        public void invalidate()
        The method will force a process cycle that may result in an CursorEvents being generated if there is a significant event that affects a Cursor. In most cases when a new position or key event is received, the Cursor internally invalidates its own data. However there may be situations where the cursor data remains the same while the scene graph is changed. This invalidate() call can help force the Cursor to run a new process loop on its existing information against the changed scene graph to generate possible CursorEvents.

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        This method returns the name of this Cursor object. Note that the name is not necessarily unique.
        Returns:
        a String representing the Cursor

      • getIoDevice

        public IoDevice getIoDevice()
        Returns the IoDevice currently attached to the Cursor.
        Returns:
        the IoDevice attached. null is no device is attached.

      • getCompatibleIoDevices

        public java.util.List<IoDevice> getCompatibleIoDevices()
        Returns a list of IoDevices compatible with the Cursor.
        Returns:
        list of compatible IoDevices

      • getSceneObject

        public GVRSceneObject getSceneObject()
        Return the GVRSceneObject associated with the Cursor object.

        This call is useful for applications that need to change the properties of the GVRSceneObject controlled by the Cursor.

        Returns:
        the GVRSceneObject representing the Cursor object.

      • getId

        public int getId()
        This method returns an integer value that can be used to uniquely identify this Cursor.
        Returns:
        an integer representing the Cursor

      • setBusyLoading

        public void setBusyLoading(boolean loading)
        Use this method to display a loading Cursor to the user. The intended usage for this method is to let the user know that the app is currently working on a task and the cursor would not respond until completion. This method should be called from the glthread.

        We leave it to the application to control the usage of this feature.

        Parameters:
        loading - shows a loading animation on the cursor if true restores it to its original state when false.

      • isBusyLoading

        public boolean isBusyLoading()
        When the application is working on a task a feedback can be given using the setBusyLoading(boolean) call. This method lets the caller know if the Cursor is busy loading or not.
        Returns:
        Return true if the Cursor is busy loading. false otherwise.

      • isEnabled

        public boolean isEnabled()
        Use this method to check if the Cursor is enabled or disabled. By default every Cursor object is enabled.s
        Returns:
        true if the Cursor is enabled, false otherwise.

      • setEnable

        public void setEnable(boolean value)
        When enabled the Cursor would report CursorEvents. Disabling the Cursor would stop the events and also remove the Cursor from the scene (if one is provided). The Cursor can be enabled and disabled from the settings menu

        true for enable, false for disable.

        Default true - enabled.

        Parameters:
        value -

      • addCursorEventListener

        public void addCursorEventListener(CursorEventListener listener)
        Register for events whenever the Cursor updates its position or receives button clicks.
        Parameters:
        listener - the CursorEventListener to be added.null objects are ignored.

      • removeCursorEventListener

        public void removeCursorEventListener(CursorEventListener listener)
        Remove the previously added CursorEventListener.
        Parameters:
        listener - the CursorEventListener to be removed.null objects are ignored.

      • checkControllerActive

        protected void checkControllerActive(GVRCursorController controller)
        Checks if the associated GVRCursorController is active or not by checking all the KeyEvent reported by the GVRCursorController. The active state depends on the KeyEvent#getAction() of the latest KeyEvent.
        Parameters:
        controller - The GVRCursorController associated with the Cursor

      • handleControllerEvent

        protected void handleControllerEvent(GVRCursorController controller,
                                     boolean sentEvent)

      • getAvailableIoDevices

        public java.util.List<IoDevice> getAvailableIoDevices()
        Get a list of currently available IoDevices to use with the Cursor. The Cursor defines a list of compatible IoDevices in the settings.xml. This method returns a subset from the compatible list of IoDevices that are available to the framework and not being used by any other cursor.
        Returns:
        a list of available IoDevice.

      • attachIoDevice

        public void attachIoDevice(IoDevice ioDevice)
                    throws java.io.IOException
        Use this method to attach an available IoDevice to the Cursor. The currently attached IoDevice is released and a new IoDevice is attached to the Cursor.
        Parameters:
        ioDevice - the IoDevice to attach, this IoDevice should be one of the objects returned by getAvailableIoDevices()
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - The call return an IOException if this IoDevice cannot be attached.

      • lookAt

        protected void lookAt()
        This method makes sure that the Cursor is always facing the camera. Lookat implemented using:

        http://mmmovania.blogspot.com/2014/03/making-opengl-object-look-at-another.html
